A Co3O4 Nano-needles Mesh for High-efficient, High-flux Emulsion Separation
Yuee Chen, a Nü Wang,* ab Fengyun Guo,a Lanlan Hou,a Jingchong Liu,a Jing Liu,a Yue Xu,*a Yong Zhao a and Lei Jiang a
A Co3O4 nano-needles steel mesh was prepared by a facile hydrothermal synthesis and subsequent calcination method. The mesh is superhydrophilic in air and superoleophobic low-adhesive underwater. More importantly, the mesh exhibits outstanding chemical stability even in strong basic and high-concentration salt solutions, which accomplishes the separation of alkaline and saline oil-in-water emulsions with high efficiency (above 99%) and high flux (2000 L m −2 h −1 ).
Water and oil mixtures are extensively encountered in marine oil exploitation, chemical engineering, machining, metal smelting, food, pharmacy industries as well as daily life. Separation of oily water has become a global concern because quite large amount of these mixtures are discharged without proper treatment, which seriously threaten marine ecological safety and human health. 1-3 A variety of traditional techniques, such as centrifuges, magnetic separators, flotation technologies, and oil absorption materials, have been used to separate oil/water mixtures. 4-10 These methods usually suffer, however, from tedious processing, low efficiency, high cost and secondary pollution. Membrane separation technology, which have advantages of simple separation equipment and low energy consumption, is considered to be one of the most environmental friendly and effective method for the separation of oil/water mixtures in large-scale processing. 11-12 Membrane separation technology based on special wettability has made significant progress in the last decade. For example, a superhydrophobic/superoleophilic membrane could be used to filter oil from water, 13-19 while a superhydrophilic/ underwater superoleophobic membrane could filter water from oil. 20-25 Nonetheless, the mentioned membranes above are only suitable for separation of free oil and water rather
than emulsified oil/water mixture.
Emulsion is a kind of oil/water mixture that one phase uniformly and stably disperses in another phase in form of tiny droplets normally less than 20 µm. 26 An emulsified oil/water mixture is liable to be formed with relatively high stability and a complex structure, so that it is far more difficult to deal with than simple free oil/water mixture. 27 An effective emulsion separation membrane has to satisfy two basic conditions including suitable pore size and wettability. 28 On one hand, the pore size of the membrane must be less than diameter of emuslion droplets, only then can the membrane play an effective screening role in separation process. On the other hand, the membrane should be wettable for continuous phase while good liquid repellency for dispersed phase. Accordingly, some porous polymer membranes with special wettability have been prepared and used for the separation of oil/water emulsions 29-33 , such as poly(vinylidene fluoride) membrane, 29 hydrogel modified filter paper, 30 double-skinned flat-sheet cellulose acetate membrane, 31 etc. These polymer membranes exhibited excellent emulsion separation performance on various water and relative inert oils such as gasoline or diesel. Meanwhile, inorganic membranes, have drawn more and more attentions due to their excellent solvent resistance, thermal stability and good anti-fouling performance, which meet the demands of high-flux, continuous oil/water emulsion separation. 34-40 For instance, silica nanofibrous membrane, tungsten-oxide-coated mesh and TiO2 nanocluster-based mesh have been fabricated and applied in emulsion separation. 36-38 However, for the separation of strong alkali emulsion and highconcentration salt emulsion, there are still few literature reports. Herein, we report a Co3O4 nano-needles coated steel mesh fabricated by a facile hydrothermal synthesis and subsequent calcination method. The as-obtained mesh shows superhydrophilicity in air and superoleophobicity underwater, it can effectively separate not only common neutral emulsions, but also strong alkali emulsion and high-concentration salt emulsion. Such chemical stable, high-efficient (above 99%) and high-flux (2000 L m −2 h −1 ) mesh matches well with the real

The key for high-efficient and high-flux emulsion separation is to build a porous media with small pore size less than size of dispersed droplets and high porosity. But these two factors are normally contradictory. To solve this dilemma, here we grew a layer of high dense Co3O4 nano-needles onto stainless steel mesh by a fluorine-mediated hydrothermal synthesis and calcination method. 41-43 Such combination achieves a good balance between small pore size and high porosity. Fig 1a shows the original stainless steel mesh (SSM), which has an average pore diameter of 16.3 µm (see Fig S1) and a smooth surface as inset shown. The pristine SSM could not be applied for emulsion separation due to large pore size. Therefore, we adopted a hydrothermal method to fill the mesh holes by Co3O4 nano-needles. After the SSM was put into a autoclave containing Co(NO3)2, NH4F, and H2NCONH2 solution, cobalt ion would hydrolyze to Co(OH)F and Co(OH)(CO3)0.5•0.11H2O with NH4F as mediate in the alkali environment of urea at 120 o C. The corresponding reaction process and reaction mechanism were shown in experimental section and Scheme S1 in Support Information. These cobalt precursors would transform to needle-like Co3O4 nanostructures after calcination. The length and density of cobalt compounds nano-needles increased with extending the reaction time. After 2 hours hydrothermal reaction and subsequent calcination, few small needles grew on SSM (Fig S2). When the hydrothermal reaction time prolonged to 6 h, the SSM was fully covered with a layer of uniform Co3O4 nano-needles arrays after subsequent calcination (Fig 1b and Fig S2). (The SEM images of Co3O4 nano-needles mesh before calcination were shown in Fig S3). It could be seen that the mesh pores were completely filled by the dense crossed nano-needles without defect or crack. This defect free dense nano-needles structure is vital important for emulsion separation because it has no short-circuit for emulsified tiny droplets, which guarantees a high separation efficiency. Fig 1c and 1d further exhibit the bird-view and cross-section of the mesh surface with nano-needles. It could be seen that the length of nano-needles is about 5 µm and the nano-needles grow vertically to the mesh wires. A highmagnification image clearly shows the needle structure of Co3O4 with sharp tips (Fig 1e). XRD pattern shows that all the diffraction peaks of the mesh match well with the standard card of spinel Co3O4 (JCPDS Card No: No. 43-1003), except for those peaks arising from the SSM (marked with ■), indicating that the cobalt precursor has completely turned into crystalline Co3O4 after annealing (Fig 1f and Fig S4). The synthesis includes two crucial steps, formation of the precursor via a hydrothermal process and subsequent calcination to Co3O4. 42, 44 (1) Hydrothermal process

Comparing to the cobalt precursors of Co(OH)F and Co(OH)(CO3)0.5·0.11H2O, Co3O4 has a much better tolerance towards alkali aqueous solution (Fig S5). The surfaces of the precursor meshes were damaged after 1.0 mol L −1 NaOH aqueous solution (pH = 14) immersion for 1 h, while the Co3O4 nano-needles meshes (Co3O4 NNM) had no obvious change after the same base immersion for 1 h, which enable it a good membrane material for emulsion separation in harsh environments. Photographs of the original SSM, Co3O4 NNM, and the water contact angle (CA) and oil contact angle (OCA) underwater are shown in Fig 1g and 1h. Because both SSM and Co3O4 NNM are intrinsic hydrophilic, water could completely spread on these two meshes. However, when they were put underwater, they showed different oleophobicity. Besides the suitable pore size, a distinct wettability difference for the two phase liquids of a emulsion also plays an important role in high efficienct and high flux emulsion separation. An ideal separation membrane should be of highly wettable property for continuous phase, which allows quick passthrough of the liquid. At the same time, it must possesses high repellency for the dispersed phase that could effectively intercept the dispersed tiny droplets due to repulsive forces provided by small size lyophobic pores of the membrane. As mentioned above, the as-prepared Co3O4 NNM is of good underwater superoleophobicity. Then we further investigated the spreading behavior of water on the Co3O4 NNM by a highspeed camera. When a water droplet (4 μL) touched the mesh surface, it spreaded very quickly within 0.12 s (Fig 2a). It is worth noting that a tiny droplet remained hanging on the nozzle tip when the water droplet touched the as-prepared surface. This phenomenon is a good evidence to demonstrate the superhydrophilicity of the mesh. It arises from the strong attractive force of the mesh surface, which leads to the instant breaking up of the droplet near the mesh and a tiny drop of residue on the nozzle tip. 45 These results indicate that the Co3O4 NNM is of high water affinity. The water-favoring property could further be supported by measuring the waterreserving ability of the membranes. As shown in Fig 2b, the water capture percentage of the Co3O4 NNM reaches up to 50.6 wt%, which is over four times greater than that of bare SSM (12.5 wt%). As shown in Fig 3, underwater oil-adhesion force measurements were conducted on the original stainless steel mesh (a) and the as-prepared Co3O4 nano-needles stainless steel mesh (b) using oil droplets (1,2-dichloroethane) as detecting probes. Each measurement includes three steps: (1) before the oil droplet contacts the surface, (2) the oil dropletis pressed by the mesh, (3) the oil droplet is leaving the surface, (4) after the oil droplet leaves the surface. The original stainless steel mesh shows a larger oil-adhesion force than the Co3O4 nano-needles stainless steel mesh. Such underwater superoleophobic and low adhesion property can effectively protect the Co3O4 NNM from being polluted by oil during the oil-in-water emulsion separation process.
To evaluate the performance of the Co3O4 NNM in emulsion separation, various oil-in-water emulsions were prepared and filtered by a home-made setup as shown in Fig 4a. During the permeation process, the small oil droplets in the emulsion were captured by the Co3O4 needle-like structure, 37 which made small droplets aggregate into large droplets on the membrane surface, and then followed the sieving effect, 28 oil will be rejected on the membrane surface and clear water will flow down and pass through the mesh. As a demonstration, we made a relative stable gasoline-in-water emulsion by injecting gasoline into water in a ratio of 1:100 v/v. The optical microscope photograph of the emulsion showed that the oil droplets were uniformly dispersed in water (Fig 4b). When such emulsion passing through the Co3O4 NNM, a clear and transparent filtrate was obtained, and no oil droplets were observed in the filtrate (Fig 4c). Dynamic light scattering (DLS) of five kinds of oil-in-water emulsion was shown in Fig S6. A Tyndall experiment clearly showed the emulsion before and after separation. It is seen that the original emulsion is milky white with a clear red light beam, while the filtrate is colorless transparent without Tyndall effect (Fig 4d). Then the separation fluxes of several common oil-in-water emulsions including petroleum ether-in-water, xylene-in-water, cyclohexane-in-water, isooctane-in-water and gasoline-inwater were tested. The results showed that the fluxes were 160-340 L m -2 h -1 at ordinary pressure for different emulsions. When a smaller negative pressure (-5 KPa) was applied, the flux was dramatically increased to as high as 2005 L m −2 h −1 (Fig 4e). It means that a high emulsion separation rate could be achieved just by a quite low vacuum. These flux values are several times higher than those of traditional filtration membranes, 49-50 and other reported inorganic membranes (the flux with inorganic ZnO-Co3O4 overlapped membrane was 100- 300 L m −2 h −1 , and the flux with silica nanofibrous membrane was 892 L m −2 h −1 ), 35-36 which exhibits a promising application in emulsion separation. The high flux of emulsion separation with our Co3O4 nano-needles mesh attributes to the mesh’s good mechanical properties, which is robust enough to successfully separate emulsion driven by the pressure (-5 KPa). Further, after a high-pressure (95 KPa) water impact test, the morphology of as-prepared Co3O4 nano-needles mesh had no visible change (see Fig S7). Besides flux, a high separation
efficiency is also an important evaluation index for a qualified emulsion separation membrane. Here we characterized the oil content of filtrate by using the infrared spectrometer oil content analyzer, and the oil rejection coefficient (R, %) could be calculated according to:

Where Cƒ and Co are the oil concentrations of the collected water and the original oil/water emulsion, respectively. 51-52 As shown in Fig 4f, the separation efficiencies for different emulsions are all higher than 99% even under high-flux. Besides, the separation performance of Tween 80 stabilized emulsion with our as-prepared Co3O4 nano-needles mesh was also above 99%, as shown in Fig S8.
It should be noted that the emulsions we separated above were all pure water and oil systems, but the actual industrial production or waste emissions are often very complex, such as strong basic and high-concentration salt condition. These complex systems are giant challenge for separation membrane. In separation process, water phase will directly contact with membrane materials, the stability of the materials against strong alkali and high-concentration salt solutions would be very important. In this work, the as-prepared Co3O4 NNM shows outstanding anti-alkali and anti-salt capacity. It is seen that the as-prepared mesh still exhibites good superoleophobicity in 1.0 mol L −1 NaOH (pH = 14), and 1.0 mol L −1 NaCl aqueous solutions, respectively (Fig 5a-b). Then two kinds of emulsions were made from gasoline and abovementioned 1.0 mol L −1 NaOH and 1.0 mol L −1 NaCl aqueous solutions, respectively. The separation performance of the mesh was examined by continuous emulsion separation for 1 h under a suction vacuum pressure of 5 KPa. The results show

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: A Co3O4 nano-needles coated stainless steel mesh was fabricated by a simple hydrothermal synthesis and subsequent calcination method. This mesh shows superhydrophilicity in air and low-adhesive superoleophobicity underwater that successfully accomplished the separation of oil-in-water emulsions with high efficiency and high flux. More importantly, the mesh is of good chemical stability even in strong basic, and high-concentration salt emulsions, and the separation efficiency of Co3O4 NNM for alkaline and saline emulsions remained above 99%, which made it a good membrane material for emulsified oil/water separation in harsh environments. The material is a promising candidate for the practical treatment of wastewater produced by industry and households in the real complex environment.
